awd_titl_txt: Conference: IEEE ICHI 2023 Doctoral Consortium Program
awd_abstract_narration:
This project requests support for doctoral students to attend the IEEE International Conference on Healthcare Informatics (ICHI2023) in Houston, TX, USA. ICHI2023 provides a supportive scientific forum for students focusing on computing, health- and bioinformatics. It provides a forum for expert and peer critique of students' research with the goal of improving their science. Student participants will also have the opportunity to receive networking support and career advice from internationally recognized experts. This proposal supports doctoral students by providing a Student Doctoral Consortium focused on encouraging students to learn from peers and experts from multiple perspectives to understand how innovative computing and informatics combine to make the most impact in the area of health. In addition, student participation in rapid talks and roundtable sessions at the conference enables students to explore their science and see different career paths for researchers in this area. 
 
The ICHI2013 conference exposes participants to different scientific disciplinary approaches, supports networking with conference attendees, and is designed to support the development of the next generation of scholars in health- and bioinformatics. Overall, the travel support brings together students with experts who might not otherwise engage with one another and engage in multidisciplinary science in the area of health. This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impact review criteria.

inst.inst_name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

por.por_cntn:
IEEE International Conference on Healthcare Informatics (ICHI) is the premier community forum focusing on the application of computer science principles, information science principles, information technology, and communication technology to address problems in healthcare, public health, and everyday wellness. The conference highlights the most novel technical contributions in computing-oriented health informatics and the related social and ethical implications.

The conference exposes participants to different scientific disciplinary approaches, supports networking with conference attendees, and is designed to support the development of the next generation of scholars in health- and bioinformatics. Overall, the support brings together students with experts who might not otherwise engage with one another and engage in multidisciplinary science in health.

The doctoral consortium offers a supportive learning opportunity for students in the early stage of their research on health informatics problems. Participants discuss their work in progress and receive feedback and guidance from mentors. Students benefit from meeting with leading researchers and receive valuable guidance on the direction of their dissertation, specific issues in health informatics, as well as career development.

In 2023, IEEE ICHI was held June 26-29, in person, in Houston, Texas (https://ieeeichi.github.io/ICHI2023/), and 11 students attended. Among them, 6 students are female, and 2 of them are minority students, i.e., African American students from Howard University. All the selected students were in the early stages of their program and were currently attending doctoral programs at the Indiana University, Columbia University, University of Illinois Chicago, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Texas A&M University, University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, University of South Carolina, Howard University, North Carolina State University, USA, and Imperial College London, UK. Only US students were financially sponsored by this grant.

Their doctoral consortium submissions are published and available from IEEE Xplore, 2023 IEEE 11th International Conference on Healthcare Informatics (ICHI), which can be accessed at https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/conhome/1803080/all-proceedings.

The consortium chairs were Dezhi Wu, University of South Carolina, and Gondy Leroy, University of Arizona. The doctoral consortium comprised two half-day programs starting at 1 PM to 4:30 PM on June 26, and from 8.30 am to 12.00 pm on June 27, 2023. The program comprised an elevator speech exercise where attendees received instructions on how to craft an elevator speech, the opportunity to practice with peer-mentoring, as well as final delivery of the speech. This served as an introduction to the group. During the remainder of the doctoral consortium program, each participant presented their research and received constructive feedback on the research and presentation.  The program also included a panel with as moderator Gondy Leroy, and as panelists: Christopher Yang, Drexel University, USA, Hua Xue, Yale University, USA, Laila Rasmy Gindy Bekhet, University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, TX, USA, and Caro Combi, University of Verona, Italy on June 26 afternoon, and concluded with a field research tour BioScience Research Collaborative (BRC)’s Laboratories at Rice University, where students were able to experience cutting-edge robotics, AI-driven healthcare research projects and interacted with scientists to broaden their view of healthcare informatics research on June 27, 2023.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2023
Modified by: Dezhi Wu
